newsitem.title: UK: IATA attacks U.K. airport tax rise, noise limits.
newsitem.headline: IATA attacks U.K. airport tax rise, noise limits.

text.p: The UK budget decision to double the country's airport departure tax from winter 1997 is "arbitrary and cynical", International Air Transport Association(IATA) director, Pierre Jeanniot said on Monday.

"These taxes ..ten pounds to travel to the EU and 20 pounds .. to go elsewhere have nothing to do with aviation. They are unfair and totally discriminatory," he told a conference on the future of air transport.

"The problem with taxes such as the UK air departure tax is a total lack of accountability. There is no link between the activity ...in this case air travel...the tax and the government's attitude to the activity, he added.
"What we have at the moment is Robin Hood taking money from anyone walking to an international departure gate and giving it, not to the poor, but to the Sheriff of Nottingham."

Jeanniot also criticised the U.K. Department of Transport's recent decision to tighten noise limits at London's three airports, " which if implemented would have made it impossible for all but the very largest large aircraft to operate economically ..from January 1."
On November 6, IATA won a High Court order suspending the new noise limits at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted until a judicial review has taken place.

The noise rules "would force all but the latest aircraft to systematically exceed the limits unless they leave behind cargo or passengers or the fuel that would take them non-stop to their destinations," he said.
